newsitem.title: CHINA: China says debt-issue increase difficult in 1997.
newsitem.headline: China says debt-issue increase difficult in 1997.

text.p: Chinese debt issues exceeded state plans in 1996, making it difficult to achieve a targeted 27-percent increase in issues in 1997, Finance Minister Liu Zhongli said in his annual budget speech on Sunday.

China's target for domestic and overseas debt in 1997 is 248.596 billion yuan ($29.95 billion), or an increase of 27.3 percent compared with 1996, "which is an arduous task", Liu told the National People's Congress, or parliament.
China would issue 57 billion yuan to cover the budget deficit in 1997, he said, and a further 195.908 billion yuan would be needed to service domestic and foreign debt.
That gives a total of 252.908 billion yuan, but a surplus of 4.312 billion yuan from bond receipts in 1996 would be deducted.
China issued 196.742 billion yuan in debt last year, or 1.485 billion yuan above the budgeted figure of 195.257 billion yuan. That marked an increase of 27 percent from 1995.
In 1996, expenditures on servicing foreign and domestic debt totalled 131.43 billion yuan, or 2.385 billion yuan less than the budgeted figure.

This was mainly because expenditures on debt servicing fell by 1.897 billion yuan due to fluctuations in foreign-exchange rates and because interest payments on domestic short-term government treasury bonds were 488 million yuan less than the budgeted figure, he said.
